sn42.8:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nālandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
sn42.8:4.2: Then Asibandhaka’s son the chief, who was a disciple of the Jains, went up to the Buddha,
sn42.8:4.3: and sat down to one side.
sn42.8:4.5: “Chief, how does Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta teach his disciples?”
sn42.8:4.6: “Sir, this is how Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta teaches his disciples:
sn42.8:4.7: ‘Everyone who kills a living creature, steal, commits sexual misconduct, or lies goes to a place of loss, to hell.
sn42.8:4.8: You’re led on by what you usually live by.’
sn42.8:4.9: This is how Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta teaches his disciples.”
sn42.8:4.10: “‘You’re led on by what you usually live by’: if this was true, then, according to what Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta says, no-one would go to a place of loss, to hell.
sn42.8:5.1: What do you think, chief? Take a person who kills living creatures. If we compare periods of time during the day and night, which is more frequent: the occasions when they’re killing or when they’re not killing?”
sn42.8:5.2: “The occasions when they’re killing are less frequent, while the occasions when they’re not killing are more frequent.”
sn42.8:5.3: “‘You’re led on by what you usually live by’: if this was true, then, according to what Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta says, no-one would go to a place of loss, to hell.
sn42.8:6.1: What do you think, chief? Take a person who kills steals …
sn42.8:8.1: lies. If we compare periods of time during the day and night, which is more frequent: the occasions when they’re lying or when they’re not lying?”
sn42.8:8.2: “The occasions when they’re lying are less frequent, while the occasions when they’re not lying are more frequent.”
sn42.8:8.3: “‘You’re led on by what you usually live by’: if this was true, then, according to what Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta says, no-one would go to a place of loss, to hell.
sn42.8:9.1: Take some teacher who has this doctrine and view:
sn42.8:9.2: ‘Everyone who kills a living creature, steal, commits sexual misconduct, or lies goes to a place of loss, to hell.’
sn42.8:9.3: And there’s a disciple who has much confidence in that teacher.
sn42.8:9.5: ‘My teacher has this doctrine and view:
sn42.8:9.6: ‘Everyone who kills a living creature, steal, commits sexual misconduct, or lies goes to a place of loss, to hell.’
sn42.8:9.21: They get the view: ‘I too am going to a place of loss, to hell.’
sn42.8:9.22: Unless they give up that speech and thought, and let go of that view, they will be cast down to hell.
sn42.8:10.1: But consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
sn42.8:10.2: In many ways he criticizes and denounces killing living creatures, saying: ‘Stop killing living creatures!’
sn42.8:10.6: And there’s a disciple who has much confidence in that teacher.
sn42.8:10.8: ‘In many ways the Buddha criticizes and denounces killing living creatures, saying: “Stop killing living creatures!”
sn42.8:10.9: But I have killed living creatures to a certain extent.
sn42.8:10.10: That’s not right, it’s not good,
sn42.8:10.11: and I feel remorseful because of it.
sn42.8:10.12: But I can’t undo what I have done.’
sn42.8:10.13: Reflecting like this, they give up killing living creatures,
sn42.8:10.14: and in future they don’t kill living creatures.
sn42.8:10.15: That’s how to give up this bad deed
sn42.8:11.1: ‘In many ways the Buddha criticizes and denounces stealing …
sn42.8:13.2: But I have lied to a certain extent.
sn42.8:13.3: That’s not right, it’s not good,
sn42.8:13.4: and I feel remorseful because of it. But I can’t undo what I have done.’
sn42.8:13.5: Reflecting like this, they give up lying, and in future they don’t lie.
sn42.8:13.6: That’s how to give up this bad deed
sn42.8:14.1: They give up killing living creatures.
sn42.8:14.10: They give up wrong view and have right view.
sn42.8:15.1: That noble disciple is rid of desire, rid of ill will, unconfused, aware, and mindful. They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way they spread a heart full of love above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
sn42.8:15.2: In the same way they spread a heart full of love above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
sn42.8:15.3: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
sn42.8:15.4: In the same way, when the heart’s release by love has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
sn42.8:16.1: Then that noble disciple is rid of desire, rid of ill will, unconfused, aware, and mindful. They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
sn42.8:16.2: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
sn42.8:16.3: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
sn42.8:16.4: In the same way they spread a heart full of equanimity above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
sn42.8:16.5: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
sn42.8:16.6: In the same way, when the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.”
sn42.8:17.1: When he said this, Asikabandha’s son the chief said to the Buddha:
sn42.8:17.3: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
